seg.seg: ... ... I will be (a monk), worthy of gifts from all. I will teach (the good Law) ...
… I will be (a monk), worthy of gifts for all. (cf 147)
... Carrying out the unsurpassable and excellent task of Buddhahood I will go to the nirvāṇa. This voice of the venerable Maitreya is (to be heard).
Carrying out the unsurpassable and excellent task of the Buddha rank I will go to the nirvāṇa.
For this reason many people [and] beings are released from the three bad classes of existence. || Having heard that (the beings) on earth (and in heaven) were amazed ...
Deswegen werden viele Menschen aus den drei schlechten Geburtsklassen erlöst.
Therefore, many people are released from the three bad classes of incarnation.
having said "sādhu sādhu", with their hands in añjali, looking at the bodhisattva, say: "Look, look, o good ones, at the venerable (bodhisattva) Maitreya, how

charming [he is]! || In the tune Keśika: || Like lightning out of a cloud, this one went out of the womb of his mother, like a golden liana. Like the Kesarin lion he looks in the four directions. Having made seven steps
Wie ein Blitz aus einer Wolke (ging) er (aus dem) Bauch der Mutter wie eine goldene Liane (heraus); wie ein Kesara-Löwe schaute er in die vier Himmelsrichtungen...
Like a thunderbolt from a cloud he (went out of [his]) mother's belly like a golden liana; like a kesara lion he looked in the four directions ...
like the stars of the Big Dipper, making the golden earth bow. He illuminated the whole world with rays and made it resound with his voice. Thereupon, in all of heaven and earth (the gods

and the mortals) revere the venerable Maitreya with great respect. || Thereupon, the father of Maitreya, the purohita Brahmāyu, as if dazed both with joy and by the fact that the chance is given by the divine
kings, according to his desire to see the bodhisattva, frightened, as if were, he goes to the bodhisattva with restraint. Thereupon, due to the fruit of the good actions of the bodhisattva,
two divine streams of water fell down from (the sky), the first warm, the second cold. With that the bodhisattva undergoes the cleansing. Thereupon, in front of the glorious mother ...
... a jewel fountain full of water appears. With that, she performs the cleansing, according to her intention. || In the tune Tuṣitabhavana: || A white divine parasol (is) always (turning over
the charming head) of the Bodhisattva. It is raining amidst perfumes divine lotuses, kumuda, sumana, puṇḍarika flowers ... (with) bejeweled ...
they seize ... of the bodhisattva. Because of the glory ... (on earth and) in the sky, all beings rejoice with happiness. 1
with ... flowers ... (at the feet of) the bodhisattva having placed both knees on the ground ... (with his head adorned) with a top knot of blue hair ...
... this golden earth, as it were, ...

p.note: This fragment contains part of the eleventh act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami XI, 11a6-12a12. See also 199-200.
Fragment of a manuscript which includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. 64-5). Lines a1 and b8 are lost.
The Old Turkic parallel is edited in 332-334 (text) and 352-355 (translation).

The restitution of the absolutive form ṣikoräṣ is admittedly uncertain. The phrase ṣikās ṣikoräṣ would match the figura etymologica [[ṣikonta]] attested in TB (e.g. in b6). A preterite stem of class I would complement the subjunctive V attested in TB (cf. ). The restoration proposed in Siegling's personal copy of p. 133 does not complete the colon.
The expression [[wraṣi]] is a calque of the Sanskrit compound udakakṛtya, which occurs in the parallel episode in the Mahāvadānasūtra (Vorgang 5e).
The form preceding [[pyāpyās|pyā(py)ā(s)]] is most probably a verb form with a 3sg suffixed pronoun. One possibility would be to correct and restore swāsästr-äṃ "s/he lets rain".

133 read . However, the nominative singular is incompatible with the Old Turkic parallel, in which the Purohita Brahmāyu lays his head at the feet of the Bodhisattva (bodiswt adaqınga 12a 6-7, cf. the translation in 354). The Old Turkic version uses an uninflected form (bodiswt), rather than a genitive, which may indicate the use of a possessive adjective in the Tocharian original.

a2-a3. The meter is most probably 4x17 (6/6/5).

The Old Turkic version uses an uninflected form (bodiswt), rather than a genitive, which may indicate the use of a possessive adjective in the Tocharian original.
